Title: Supreme Court takes up South Carolina's effort to defund Planned Parenthood

Title: The bald eagle isn't actually America's national bird — but that's poised to change

Title: What we learned from Elian Gonzalez, 25 years later

Immediately, his fate became the subject of an international debate: Should he stay in the U.S.? Or should he be returned to Cuba, to live with his father? From our play cousins at Futuro Studios, this is part of their series Chess Piece: The Elián González Story.We want to hear from you! Please tell us what you think about Code Switch by taking our short survey. Thank you!

Title: Trains, tracks, and tradition: Lionel celebrates 125 years of Christmas fun
Description: Lionel trains turns 125, celebrating more than a century of holiday magic. From historic models to smartphone-controlled locomotives, these iconic toy trains continue to captivate kids and collectors alike. (Image credit: Sara Messinger for NPR)

Title: The American industry that wants more government intervention

Description: Syrian refugees living in Lebanon grapple with whether to return home now that Bashar al-Assad's dictatorship has fallen. Many are hesitating.

Title: At least 25 killed after an overcrowded boat capsizes in Congo

Description: Critics warn argue that people planning to live through an atomic blast aren't focusing on the real and current dangers posed by nuclear threats. (Image credit: Jae C. Hong)

Title: Deadly violence in Nigeria tied to United Methodist Church schism over LGBTQ policies
Description: A religious schism has turned deadly in Nigeria, with a church member fatally shot and two young children killed as homes were set ablaze, according to United Methodist News Service. (Image credit: Peter Smith)

Title: Man set to be put to death in Indiana's first execution in 15 years
Description: Barring intervention by Gov. Eric Holcomb, Corcoran is scheduled to be executed before sunrise Wednesday at the Indiana State Prison in Michigan City. (Image credit: Erin Hooley)

Description: Watson, 55, and the now-defunct company were found guilty last summer of charges including wire fraud conspiracy. He has denied the allegations and plans to appeal. (Image credit: Stefan Jeremiah/AP)

Description: As sports betting has spread across the U.S., college athletes have increasingly faced harassment from bettors. A federal ban on wagers that concern individual performances could help, the NCAA says. (Image credit: Kevin Dietsch)

Title: Luigi Mangione is indicted on murder charges for killing healthcare CEO
Description: A New York grand jury has indicted the man accused of killing United Healthcare CEO Brian Thompson. Luigi Mangione faces murder charges for allegedly gunning Thompson down in a targeted attack.

Title: Ukraine's security service confirms it was behind assassination of Russian general
Description: A Russian lieutenant general accused of using banned chemicals on Ukrainian soldiers was assassinated Tuesday in Moscow.

Title: Turns out the bald eagle wasn't the official U.S. bird until this week
Description: It wasn't until this week that Congress passed a law making the bald eagle the official U.S. bird. And one man spearheaded the effort to get this done.

Title: Killer is identified in Wisconsin school shooting
Description: Authorities in Madison, Wisc., don't yet know what led a student to open fire at Abundant Life Christian School killing a teacher, a fellow student and injuring six others.

Title: A family reunites after years of separation during Assad regime in Syria
Description: A Syrian mother and daughter are reunited for the first time in 6 years after the fall of the Assad regime, and freedom of movement returns to the country.

Title: The Indian Movie Acclaimed Abroad But Snubbed at Home
Description: The film 'All We Imagine As Light' is an Indian film that has won rare international acclaim from Cannes and the Golden Globes. But at home in India the international buzz was ignored and it was passed over as India's entry for the Oscars. Our correspondent in Mumbai, where the film was shot, explores why it is not receiving the same acclaim in India.

Title: Luigi Mangione is charged with murder as an act of terrorism in CEO's death

Description: EasyKnock, the subject of the probe, announced its sudden closure earlier this month.

Title: Most U.S. shootings are done by men, but the Wisconsin school attack is an exception
Description: Authorities say a 15-year-old girl carried out the shooting that killed two and wounded several at a Wisconsin school. Female shooters are relatively rare, statistically speaking. (Image credit: Andy Manis)

Description: Survivors of the Syrian regime's chemical attacks are free now speak about how they lost their families. We meet people who endured attacks that Syria's former president used to stay in power.

Title: How the holidays could be affecting your medical care
Description: A new study suggests that holidays can affect your provider's decision making. (Image credit: Tatyana)

Description: As horrific details emerge from Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad's jails, many question the man who once claimed to champion their cause.

Description: In Madison, Wisconsin, authorities are trying to understand why a teenage student opened fire at their Christian school, killing a teacher and a fellow student. A half-dozen others were injured.

Title: Apprenticeships are a trending alternative to college — but there's a hitch
Description: Apprenticeships are becoming a popular alternative to college as a career path. But demand is outpacing the supply of employers who offer them. (Image credit: Megan Jelinger)

Title: FBI warns Americans to keep their text messages secure: What to know
Description: The U.S. believes hackers affiliated with China's government are infiltrating telecoms and stealing users' data. The FBI has urged people to use end-to-end encryption to keep their info safe. (Image credit: Damien Meyer)

Title: Love Is Blind' cast are employees, labor board says. Could a reality TV union be next?
Description: The case could have big implications for what glues reality show fans to the tube. A pending ruling, whatever the outcome, would set a precedent that other unscripted TV cast members could follow. (Image credit: Netflix)

Title: Cities find a new incentive to close homeless shelters
Description: A Supreme Court ruling eliminated the requirement of sheltering homeless people in some states. Advocates worry the ruling also motivates cities hostile to shelters to get rid of them altogether.

Title: Coffee prices are higher than ever. Here's what it means for your cup
Description: Droughts in top coffee-growing countries have shrunk the supply of beans. Supermarket brands like Nescafé and Folgers have already raised prices — but the world keeps drinking more and more coffee. (Image credit: Pierre Andrieu/AFP via Getty Images)

Description: The earthquake was centered 10 miles west of Port Vila, the largest city in Vanuatu, a group of 80 islands that is home to about 330,000 people. (Image credit: Dan McGarry)

Description: The stunning move raised questions about how much longer the prime minister of nearly 10 years — whose popularity has plummeted due to concerns about inflation and immigration — can stay on. (Image credit: Justin Tang)

Description: As Syria's economy collapsed during the civil war, the country became something of narco-state. The now-ousted regime was estimated to earn billions annually from trafficking a drug known as Captagon.

Description: As the future of Syria begins to emerge, one minority group is particularly fearful about how they'll be treated. The Alawites feel like they were mistreated by now-deposed dictator Bashar al-Assad, but because he was a member of that sect, they are also unfairly tied to him in the minds of other Syrians. We go to an Alawite neighborhood of Damascus to hear their concerns.

Description: Police say a student at Abundant Life Christian School in Madison Wisconsin opened fire at the school. At least three people including the shooter were found dead and several others were injured.

Title: Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson, a longtime theater lover, makes her Broadway debut

Description: When Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad fled the country, members of his own minority sect say he left them impoverished and stained with his legacy.

Description: NPR's Leila Fadel, Jane Arraf, and Ruth Sherlock share their reporting from Syria more than a week after the fall of the Assad regime.

Title: Disney's 'Moana' puts a spotlight on ancient Pacific tradition of wayfinding
Description: Wayfinding, the art of sea navigation without modern tools, takes center stage in Disney's 'Moana' films. NPR's Steve Inskeep talks t0 an expert about wayfinding and its cultural significance.

Description: NPR's Steve Inskeep talks to Stacie Pettyjohn of the Center for a New American Security, about why the federal government hasn't provided more details about drones spotted over some East Coast states.

Description: A Christmas tree farm in the Smoky Mountains tries to bring 'joy to the world' each season.

Description: A German-language Christmas choir in Austin, Texas, has been in operation since 1879. NPR joins the choir as they rehearse for their annual Christmas concert.

Description: A Navajo woman who has spent 50 years sewing has now been honored with an NEA award for her unique quilts. She is unafraid to criticize the mainstream culture that's marginalized Indigenous artists.

Description: Lancaster County, Pennsylvania, residents Fay and Bob Wenrich divorced in 1975. Now, at ages 89 and 94, and after nearly half a century apart, they've re-married.

Description: Lawmakers are set to vote for a second time on an impeachment motion against President Yoon Suk Yeol over his controversial Dec. 3 martial law decree. (Image credit: Ahn Young-joon)

Description: At issues is whether the charity Catholic Charities is qualified to be exempt from state unemployment taxes as a religious institution. (Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

Description: Three years ago, councilmembers in Washington, D.C., approved a tax hike on the wealthy as a way to raise the wages of child care workers. It's led to big gains for the city's child care workforce.

Description: Travis Timmerman, the missing American found wandering barefoot in the Syrian capital after being released from prison - is going home. NPR were there when for the moment he was welcomed home.

Description: Even in war, Lebanon's migrant workers -- many of them South Asian -- play cricket weekly. A vacant lot has become a space for the marginalized, with Filipina cooks and Syrian refugees joining in.

Description: Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton filed the lawsuit against a New York doctor who prescribed abortion pills for a client near Dallas, pitting an abortion ban against laws that protect physicians. (Image credit: David Erickson)

Title: Can Syria avoid another slide into autocracy?
Description: The brutal regime of Bashar al Assad fell over the weekend with dizzying speed. Syrians within the country and around the world burst into celebration. Now, the rebel group Hay'at Tahrir al Sham, or HTS has to govern. They are designated a terrorist organization by the US.And some worry that HTS could slide into its own kind of autocratic regime.That fear is not unfounded. Across the Middle East and North Africa, many revolutions have overthrown autocrats, only for those countries to descend back into chaos or a more oppressive rule.The Syrian revolution began amid a wave of uprisings in the region that led to new, undemocratic regimes. Can Syria avoid a similar fate today? For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider...

These men are accused of working to silence others, but they say they've found themselves silenced as well. Title: A former prisoner shares what life was like in the infamous Sednaya prison in Syria
Description: Omar Alshogre spent time in Sednaya prison in Syria. He gives a real-life look at what life was like there, and what it was like to escape and live as a civilian.

Title: What was the worst year of your life and what did you learn from it? We want to hear
Description: All Things Considered wants to hear your stories. What was your worst year ever, how did you get through it, and what did you learn from it? (Image credit: Katherine Du)

Title: Missing American is among the thousands released from Syria's notorious prisons
Description: An American was found wandering shoeless on the streets of Syria's capital, Damascus, after being released from one of the notorious Syrian regime prisons.

Title: At 18, India's Gukesh Dommaraju becomes the youngest World Chess Champion ever
Description: Dommaraju unseated China's Ding Liren to become the new world chess champion. 'Every chess player wants to experience this moment, and very few get the chance,' Dommaraju said after the match. (Image credit: Simon Lim)

Title: Ukraine Struggles to Keep the Power On Under Russian Bombardment
Description: Russia continues to pound Ukraine with missile strikes, often targeting infrastructure like power plants. That has caused Ukrainians to endure power cuts even during the harsh winter. Our correspondent visits a power plant to see what it takes to keep the lights on in war.

Title: FBI missed 'basic step' in its intelligence efforts ahead of Jan. 6 Capitol riot
Description: The long-awaited report from DOJ Inspector General office comes nearly four years after a crowd of Donald Trump's supporters stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021 to try to prevent Congress from certifying Joe Biden's election win. (Image credit: Brent Stirton)

Title: Trump says Kari Lake will lead Voice of America. He attacked it during his first term
Description: If successful, Trump's move would install a loyalist at the helm of the network. A U.S. judge found Trump appointees illegally violated Voice of America's journalistic independence in his first term. (Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)

Title: FAA chief Mike Whitaker announces that he will step down in January
Description: Mike Whitaker says he will step down as head of the Federal Aviation Administration on Jan. 20. It's not unusual for FAA administrators to resign at the change of administration, though some have stayed longer. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: Missing American Travis Timmerman found wandering barefoot outside Damascus
Description: The 29-year-old had last been seen in Budapest, Hungary. He said he was detained earlier this year after crossing into Syria on foot from Lebanon and held in prison until the fall of the Assad regime. (Image credit: Abdulaziz Ketaz)

Title: FBI Director to resign. And, UHC CEO killing brings attention to U.S. life expectancy
Description: Why FBI Director Christopher Wray will step down from the role at the end of Biden's term. And, the UHC CEO killing turns public attention to the U.S. life expectancy and health care. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: Missing American found in Syria wandering bare foot in a Damascus suburb
Description: The American identified himself Travis Timmerman. He says he was held for seven months in Sednaya -- a notorious prison in which thousands of people were arbitrarily detained under the Syrian regime.

Title: Some Syrian refugees in Berlin ponder returning post-Assad, others call Germany home
Description: Germany hosts almost a million Syrians who fled war and dictatorship. (Image credit: Karolin Klüppel for NPR)

Title: South Korea's Yoon defends martial law decree as an act of governance
Description: In an address to the nation, President Yoon Suk Yeol claimed the opposition-controlled parliament has been destroying the country's liberal democratic order. (Image credit: ANTHONY WALLACE)

Title: The Geminids meteor shower peaks at the end of the week. Here's what to expect
Description: The Geminids are one of the best and most visible annual meteor showers, when at least 120 meteors can usually be seen per hour. But 2024 will be different, thanks to the year's final full moon. (Image credit: Yasser al-Zayyat)

Title: On the road from Beirut to Damascus, people find their footing in a new Syria
Description: The road to Damascus tells the story of a new Syria emerging from 54 years of authoritarian rule by one family, the Assads. Today's Syria is no longer theirs.

Title: Doubts remain as Syria's new prime minister promises the country will be inclusive
Description: Syrians living inside and outside their country are trying to figure out what comes next after the Assad regime fell. We hear from Syrians along the road from Lebanon to Damascus.

Title: UHC murder suspect railed about U.S. health care. Here's what he missed
Description: The man charged in the killing of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson was critical of U.S. health care. Experts say the system's problems are complex and can't be pinned on one player or industry. (Image credit: David Berding/Getty Images for People's Action Institute)

Title: An update from southern Arizona at the most rural section of the southern U.S. border
Description: President-elect Trump campaigned on promised to take on the border crisis. NPR traveled to the most rural section of the border with Mexico -- a section in Arizona -- to see if anything has changed.

Title: South Korea' political crisis mares its image as one of Asia's leading democracies
Description: South Korea's president remains defiant, as efforts to impeach or arrest him for his declaration of martial law pick up speed. The political crisis raises questions about South Korea's democracy.

Title: Mystery ducks have been taking over a Manhattan neighborhood
Description: For years, residents of a Manhattan neighborhood have discovered tiny ducks and other toys hidden in its nooks and crannies. (Story aired on Weekend Edition Sunday on Dec. 18, 2024.)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: FBI Director Christopher Wray will step down. Where American life expectancy stands right now. Over the next two days, top DNC members will meet in D.C. to hash out rules for picking a new leadership.

Title: An explosion in the Afghan capital kills the Taliban refugee minister
Description: The explosion struck inside the ministry, killing Khalil Haqqani, officials said. His last official photo showed him at a meeting chaired by the deputy prime minister earlier Wednesday. (Image credit: AP)

Title: Judge declares mistrial over killing of gay University of Mississippi student
Description: Jimmy 'Jay' Lee's body has never been found, but a judge declared him dead. Jurors said they were unable to reach a verdict after over nine and a half hours of deliberation. (Image credit: Bruce Newman)

Title: Rights group accuses Russian mercenaries of abuses against civilians in Mali
Description: Malian armed forces, the Russia-backed Wagner Group and jihadi groups deliberately killed civilians and burned homes in Mali according to Human Rights Watch. (Image credit: AP)

Title: North Carolina GOP lawmakers enact a law eroding the Democratic governor's powers
Description: North Carolina lawmakers have enacted a law over the governor's veto that would diminish the powers afforded to his successor and other other Democratic statewide winners in the Nov. 5 elections. (Image credit: Matt Kelley)

Title: With One Regime Gone, Syrians Must Now Recreate Their Government
Description: In the aftermath of the collapse of the Assad regime in Syria, how are the insurgents planning to resurrect the state?

Title: What's next for the U.S. troops in Syria
Description: The U.S. still has troops in Syria, where they've been for a decade. Yet during the same period, the U.S. Embassy has been shuttered, complicating the work of U.S. diplomats and intelligence officers.

Title: How do the insurgents in Syria plan to resurrect the state?
Description: It's been less than a week since a coalition of opposition fighters overthrew the Syrian regime. Opposition leaders and government workers are rolling back decades of repression and corruption.

Title: The state of Arab Spring countries following Assad's fall in Syria
Description: NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Steven Heydemann, Middle East Studies director at Smith College, about how Syria might avoid replicating Arab countries that are worse off after overthrowing dictators.

Title: Drones explainer
Description: The drones have been seen above critical infrastructure like reservoirs, rail stations and military bases. The governor says there is 'no known threat,' but the FBI is still investigating. (Image credit: Scott Ingenito)

Title: Police say gun found with suspect matches casings at UnitedHealthcare CEO crime scene
Description: The New York police commissioner also said investigators matched Luigi Mangione's fingerprints with those found on items near the scene where the UnitedHealthcare CEO was fatally shot last week. (Image credit: Stefan Jeremiah)

Title: FBI Director Wray to resign at end of Biden administration
Description: Wray told employees at an FBI town hall that he is resigning next month to 'avoid dragging the Bureau deeper into the fray.' President-elect Donald Trump has already made a new pick for FBI director. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: The U.S. is facing a severe housing shortage. Will Trump's proposals help?
Description: The U.S. is short approximately four million homes. Wharton economist Ben Keys traces the beginning of the housing crisis to the 2008 financial meltdown — and says climate change is making things worse. (Image credit: Mario Tama)

Title: Saudi Arabia will host the 2034 FIFA World Cup — a controversial pick
Description: FIFA's selection of Saudi Arabia to host the World Cup was celebrated in the kingdom but criticized by human rights groups, who fear residents, visitors and migrant workers will be at risk of abuse. (Image credit: Mahmoud Khaled)

Title: Wisconsin kayaker who faked his death is back in the U.S. and in custody, police say
Description: Ryan Borgwardt disappeared in August while kayaking in Wisconsin, but an investigation revealed he intended to fake his death and had fled to Europe. Police said he willingly returned to the U.S. (Image credit: Green Lake County Sheriff Office)

Title: In South Korea, insurrection charges are closing in on the president
Description: Police, prosecutors and investigators have deemed President Yoon Suk Yeol as a suspect in a rare investigation into a sitting president for possible insurrection charges. (Image credit: SeongJoon Cho)

Title: Kimberly Guilfoyle is the latest Trump family ally chosen for an ambassadorship
Description: Kimberly Guilfoyle, who got engaged to Trump's son in 2020, is the latest appointee he's chosen from his family tree. There's a long and controversial history of presidents picking relatives for jobs. (Image credit: J. Scott Applewhite)

Title: Clues to Luigi Mangione's ideology. And, courts halt Kroger and Albertsons megamerger
Description: Murder suspect Luigi Mangione's digital footprint could provide clues to his ideology and possible motive. And, what's next for Kroger and Albertsons after courts halt megamerger. (Image credit: Hussein Malla)

Title: Following fall of Assad regime, Israeli strikes targeted airports, military sites
Description: NPR's A Martinez talks to Jonathan Panikoff of the Atlantic Council, about Israel's bombardments of Syria as the country grapples with selecting new leadership following years of brutal dictatorships.

Title: Rhode Island opens nation's first state-sanctioned overdose prevention center
Description: The facility in Providence will allow people to use illegal drugs with medical supervision. Supporters say supervised-use prevents fatal overdoses and connects users to help.

Title: With Assad regime out, Syrians grapple with what comes next
Description: Under Syria's president, a vast jail complex in the capital Damascus was known as a place where Syrians were disappeared without trial. Now it's crowded with with families searching for loved ones.

Title: SYRIA'S SEDNAYA PRISON
Description: Under Syria's president, a vast jail complex in the capital Damascus was known as a place where Syrians were disappeared without trial. Now it's crowded with with families searching for loved ones.

Title: Sednaya prison was where Assad regime would make Syrians disappear without trial
Description: Under Syria's president, a vast jail complex in the capital Damascus was known as a place where Syrians were disappeared without trial. Now it's crowded with with families searching for loved ones.

Title: One family thought they had left Syria forever. After Assad's fall, they plan to return
Description: Rehab Alkadi and her husband, Feras, fled Syria's war with their young son in 2013. They and other Syrian refugees in the U.S. are now hopeful for their country's future, even as uncertainty remains. (Image credit: Rehab Alkadi)

Title: Syrians who left their war-torn country for Germany are deciding whether to return
Description: Nearly one million Syrians who fled to Germany a decade ago look at events back home with new hope.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Syrians contemplate challenges facing the war-torn country. Authorities search social media posts of the suspect accused of killing a health care CEO. Courts halt Kroger-Albertsons grocery merger.

Title: Dreaming of a Black Utopia in Trump's America
Description: In his new book, The Black Utopians, author Aaron Robinson tells the story of how Black folks have created many different versions of utopian communities throughout history — and why those communities tend to be especially meaningful during times of political tension and racial unrest.We want to hear from our listeners about what you like about Code Switch and how we could do better. Please tell us what you think by taking our short survey, and thank you!

Title: Through 'The Loss Mother's Stone,' mothers share their grief from losing a child to stillbirth
Description: Through her work, photographer Nancy Borowick says she hopes to draw awareness to women's stories, educate Americans and destigmatize the conversation that occurs between doctors and patients. (Image credit: Nancy Borowick)

Title: Bankruptcy judge rejects The Onion's bid for Infowars
Description: The bidder that lost last month's auction of conspiracy theorist Alex Jones' assets had complained that the process was rigged and 'fatally flawed.' (Image credit: Joe Buglewicz)

Title: A suspect is in custody. Some Americans are celebrating his alleged actions
Description: Five days after UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson was shot and killed in Manhattan, police arrested 26 year old Luigi Mangione in Pennsylvania. He's facing charges including murder, the illegal possession of a firearm, and lying about his identity.Authorities believe they have arrested the person responsible for gunning down the CEO of a health insurance company. What have we learned about Luigi Mangione, and his possible motivations? For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.Email us at considerthis@npr.org. (Image credit: Jeff Swensen)

Title: The Mood Inside Syria
Description: For the first time in a generation, Syrians are no longer living under the regime of a brutal dictator. Our reporter travelled from Lebanon to Syria's capital, Damascus, talking to Syrians along the way and tells us how people are adjusting to their new reality. Sign up for State of the World+ to listen sponsor-free and support the work of NPR journalists. Visit plus.npr.org. (Image credit: Omar Haj Kadour)

Title: Israel takes credit, in part, for the fall of the Assad regime. But what now?
Description: Soon after Bashar al-Assad's regime fell in Syria, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu claimed Israel paved the way for the uprising by its attacks on Iran and its proxies.

Title: Monarch butterflies will get federal protections as a threatened species
Description: U.S. officials decided to extend protections to monarch butterflies after warnings from environmentalists that populations are shrinking and the beloved pollinator may not survive climate change. (Image credit: Sue Ogrocki)

Title: With fall of Assad regime, Austin Tice's siblings hope he'll be home soon
Description: Austin Tice has been missing in Syria for years. NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with two of his siblings, after Assad's regime fell in Syria.

Title: What could happen to the chemical weapons in Syria
Description: The news in Syria has raised immediate questions about the fate of Assad's stockpiles of chemical weapons and the continued presence of U.S. forces fighting the Islamic State in the northeast.

Title: A high school friend of Luigi Mangione remembers a teenager with enormous potential
Description: A prep-school valedictorian and Ivy-educated tech worker, Luigi Mangione grew up wealthy, smart and successful. Now police have charged the 26-year-old with the murder of UnitedHealthcare's CEO.

Title: Who is the leader of Syria's rebels? What to know about Abu Mohammed al-Golani
Description: As a new form of government starts to take shape in Syria, the armed group that led efforts to topple former President Bashar al-Assad will play a significant role. Its head may act as a power broker.

Title: NPR reports from Syria: The atmosphere in Damascus and the horrors of Saydnaya prison
Description: In Syria, people have known that one wrong step could land them in trouble with the government. For the first time in more than half a century, Syrians are experiencing life without that shadow.

Title: Netanyahu testifies about allegations of trading favors with media moguls
Description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu defended himself in court against corruption charges for allegedly trading favors with media moguls. His trial has lasted for more than four years.

Title: Kroger and Albertsons grocery megamerger halted by federal court
Description: The ruling makes it increasingly likely that Kroger might abandon its $24.6 billion plan to buy Albertsons. The merger would have combined two of America's largest supermarket chains. (Image credit: Al Behrman/AP)

Title: Trump-era Justice Department subpoenaed congressional staffers, watchdog finds
Description: But the department's internal watchdog found no evidence of political motivation by federal prosecutors. (Image credit: Tierney L. Cross)

Title: 5 things to watch as Syria confronts a new future
Description: The sudden collapse of President Bashar al-Assad has come as welcome news to many, but there are jitters both inside and outside the country about what will follow. (Image credit: Hussein Malla)

Title: Police say UnitedHealthcare's CEO was likely killed with a ghost gun. What are they?
Description: Police say the suspect had a ghost gun, possibly made with a 3D printer, when he was arrested on Monday. Here's what to know about the increasingly widespread weapons and efforts to regulate them. (Image credit: Ted Shaffrey)

Title: South Korea arrests its ex-defense minister over martial law efforts
Description: Former Defense Minister Kim Yong Hyun was formally arrested over his alleged collusion with in imposing martial law last week, as authorities investigate whether their acts amount to rebellion. (Image credit: Adrian Wyld)

Title: Arctic tundra now emits planet-warming pollution, federal report finds
Description: Arctic tundra is releasing greenhouse gases into the atmosphere as hotter temperatures melt frozen ground and wildfires increase. (Image credit: Gerald Frost)

Title: Taiwan's Defense Ministry says a large Chinese military force has been detected nearby
Description: China's secretive military appears to be up to something around Taiwan, but it's unclear whether it's a formal military drill. (Image credit: Chiang Ying-ying)

Title: What we know about murder suspect Luigi Mangione. And, why food recalls are rising
Description: Police arrested Luigi Mangione yesterday and charged him with the murder of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson last week. Here's the latest details. And, why food recalls are rising. (Image credit: Altoona Police Department)

Title: There's a post-election power struggle going on in North Carolina
Description: The GOP-led Legislature aims to take powers from offices won by Democrats. The first attempt was vetoed by the Democratic governor, but Republicans have a supermajority to override the veto.

Title: How the fall of the Assad regime in Syria may impact Russia
Description: NPR's Michel Martin talks to Russian historian Sergey Radchenko about what happens to Russia's sphere of influence in the Middle East with Assad gone.

Title: Luigi Mangione, 26, is charged in UnitedHealthcare CEO's killing
Description: With the arrest of Luigi Mangione, police have apprehended and charged a suspect in the killing of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson, though many questions remain unanswered.

Title: A phone company developed an AI 'granny' to beat scammers at their own game
Description: The company behind the scam-baiting granny said the AI technology can keep scammers on the phone for 40 minutes at a time, keeping them away from real people. (Image credit: Screenshot captured by NPR)

Title: A suspect is charged with murder in the health care CEO shooting: Here is the latest
Description: Luigi Mangione, 26, was arrested and charged with murder on Monday. He was found at a McDonald's in Pennsylvania, but is expected to be extradited to New York. (Image credit: Sydney Roach)

Title: A first in Israeli history: a sitting prime minister is testifying as a defendant
Description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is taking the witness stand in his own corruption trial. Netanyahu repeatedly had asked to delay the trial due to the Gaza war and his leadership duties.

Title: After celebrations, Syria faces an uncertain future
Description: Syrian rebels have overturned one of the oldest dictatorships in the world. It has been a long struggle, including more than a decade of civil war. But it all began in 2011, during the Arab Spring.

Title: The fall of Syria's Assad has renewed hope for the release of U.S. journalist Austin Tice
Description: Austin Tice went missing during a reporting trip in Syria in 2012. His release is a top priority for the U.S. government following a rebel group's ouster of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad. (Image credit: Joseph Eid)

Title: Communities in Mississippi, scarred by ICE raids, fear the future under Trump
Description: Some Mississippi towns saw the biggest workplace ICE raids in the country in 2019. The impact is still being felt -- as activists and immigrants brace for Trump's proposed mass-deportations.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Suspect is arrested in killing of CEO. Israel's prime minister is taking the witness stand in his own defense. Jay-Z is latest celebrity named in the web of allegations against Sean 'Diddy' Combs.

Title: Florida prosecutor seeks to overturn convictions in cocaine sting operation
Description: A Florida prosecutor says he will seek to vacate as many as 2,600 convictions of people who bought crack cocaine made by the Broward County Sheriff's Office for sting operations between 1988 and 1990. (Image credit: Amy Beth Bennett /AP)

Title: 6 charged with human smuggling in deadly 2021 Mexico truck crash
Description: The truck had been packed with at least 160 migrants when it crashed into a support for a pedestrian bridge in the Mexican state of Chiapas. (Image credit: STR)

Title: Taller vehicles are more dangerous to pedestrians, even at low speeds, research finds
Description: A study by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety shows higher speeds are worse for pedestrians regardless of vehicle height — but those risks are amplified for vehicles with taller front ends. (Image credit: Spencer Platt)

Title: What we know about Luigi Mangione, the suspect in United Healthcare CEO's killing
Description: Mangione was arraigned on firearms and forgery charges in Pennsylvania after his arrest Monday evening, and is expected to face charges in New York as well. (Image credit: Altoona Police Department)

Title: How Kash Patel has used children's books and podcasts to promote conspiracy theories
Description: Trump's pick to head the FBI has parlayed his time serving in various national security roles in the first Trump administration to building a brand promoting pro-Trump conspiracy theories. (Image credit: Dominic Gwinn)

Title: Veteran found not guilty of negligent homicide in death of homeless man on NYC subway
Description: Jurors find a Marine veteran not guilty in the chokehold killing of a homeless man who was acting erratically on a New York City subway.

Title: Massacre in Haiti leaves almost 200 dead, says UN
Description: As Haiti spirals deeper into crisis, gang violence killed nearly 200 people over the weekend. This takes the death toll in 2024 in Haiti to 5,000 people.

Title: Displaced Syrians are considering returning home now that Assad's regime has toppled
Description: With the fall of the regime in Syria, displaced Syrians around the world are contemplating what they once thought was impossible: returning home to Syria.

Title: A look back at Bashar al-Assad's rule of Syria
Description: Former Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and his family have been granted asylum in Russia and are now in Moscow. Assad's departure marks the end of nearly 25 years of brutal rule.

Title: Syrian Refugees Displaced for Years Return Home
Description: The regime of President Bashar al-Assad crumbled in rapid fashion as rebel groups challenged his power. Assad is now in exile in Russia and the rebels have taken control of the capital, Damascus. Now displaced Syrians, some of whom have been out of the country for over a decade, are returning home. Our correspondent in Lebanon spoke to some returning Syrians.

Title: Trump's border czar is in the White House, not an agency. Here's why that matters
Description: Tom Homan's perch inside the White House will give him a global view, but also pose challenges for immigration policy. (Image credit: Drew Angerer)

Title: Jay-Z is accused of raping a 13-year-old girl in a complaint filed in a civil lawsuit
Description: Jay-Z was accused of drugging and raping a 13-year-old girl, allegedly along with Sean 'Diddy' Combs, in 2000, according to a civil lawsuit filed in federal court on Sunday.

Title: For Mouaz Moustafa, the fall of the Assad regime is an emotional victory
Description: NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Mouaz Moustafa of the non-profit Syrian Emergency Task Force about the dramatic toppling of the Assad regime, as Moustafa prepares to fly back to his home city, Damascus.

Title: A record-breaking deal for slugger Juan Soto sends the baseball world into a spin
Description: The Dominican-born superstar Juan Soto will take his talents to Queens after the New York Mets reportedly signed him to a $765 million contract — a move that has the rest of the baseball world abuzz. (Image credit: Sarah Stier/Getty Images)

Title: How the fall of Assad's regime changes the geopolitics of the Middle East
Description: NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with professor Joshua Landis, who directs the Center for Middle East Studies at the University of Oklahoma, about how the fall of the Assad regime could change global dynamics.

Title: Police detain 'strong person of interest' in health insurance CEO killing
Description: Police in Altoona, Penn., detained a 26-year-old man, Luigi Mangione, who's being described as a 'strong person of interest' in the killing of health insurance CEO Brian Thompson.

Title: Soft medium, hard truths - National Endowment for the Arts recognizes a Navajo quilter
Description: A Navajo woman who has spent 50 years sewing has now been honored with an NEA award for her unique quilts. She is unafraid to criticize the mainstream culture that's marginalized Indigenous artists. (Image credit: National Museum of the American Indian, Smithsonian Institution (26/9331). Photo by NMAI Photo Services)

Title: In Lebanon, villagers on the border watch Syria's revolution with unease
Description: While Syrian refugees in Lebanon return home, many Lebanese remain on edge. Years of conflict have left the Syria-Lebanon borderlands scarred, and fears grow that instability could spill over again. (Image credit: Ayman Oghanna for NPR)

Title: Bidders are back in court battling over the auction of Alex Jones' Infowars
Description: A U.S. bankruptcy judge is hearing arguments for and against selling the show to The Onion, the satirical news site named the winning bidder. Host Alex Jones says the auction was rigged. (Image credit: Joe Buglewicz)

Title: Police make arrest in healthcare CEO shooting
Description: A man has been arrested in connection with the shooting death of healthcare CEO Brian Thompson. (Image credit: Sydney Roach)

Title: Supreme Court rejects challenge to Boston's school admissions policy
Description: The court's action was the second time the justices declined to intervene in an admissions program based on geography since their 2023 ruling invalidating affirmative action in higher education. (Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

Title: Supreme Court rejects challenge to Hawaii gun licensing rules -- for now
Description: At issue was a Hawaii State Supreme Court decision that allowed the state to prosecute a man carrying a loaded pistol without a license. (Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

Title: The Eras era ends: A look back at Taylor Swift's record-breaking, 21-month tour
Description: Swift has made over $2 billion in ticket sales and spent over 25 hours singing the 10-minute version of 'All Too Well' since March 2023. Here's a look at the historic tour and what might come next. (Image credit: Carlos Alvarez)

Title: A gang leader in Haiti is accused of massacring over 100 people
Description: A gang leader who controls a key port in Haiti's capital is accused of massacring older people and Vodou religious leaders to avenge his son's death. (Image credit: Odelyn Joseph)

Title: How Syria's revolution could reshape the Middle East
Description: The swift downfall of Bashar al-Assad is reverberating throughout the Middle East. Countries are urgently reassessing how to deal with a nation seeking to rebuild itself after years of civil war. (Image credit: Hussein Malla)

Title: Rebels seized control of Syrian capital. And, Trump's 1st post-election TV interview
Description: Rebels have seized control of Syria's capital and President Bashar al-Assad fled to Russia. And, President-elect Donald Trump reveals his plans to govern in first post-election network TV interview. (Image credit: Omar Sanadiki)

Title: For the first time in decades, an Assad is not in control of Syria
Description: AS Syrian rebels gained control of Damascus, Bashar al-Assad fled to Russia. But the excitement about a new Syria comes with uncertainty about what the future holds.

Title: Yes, the number of food recalls has been rising. Here's what you need to know
Description: Food recalls fell sharply during the COVID-19 pandemic but are on an uptick now. Here's how the government is tracing outbreaks — and some tips on handling food safely to minimize the risk of illness. (Image credit: Justin Sullivan)

Title: A look at what the fall of the Assad regime in Syria means for the U.S.
Description: President Biden said the U.S. is prepared to work with Syrians as they try to create a new government. But President-elect Trump is sounding a different note.

Title: South Korea's Justice Ministry imposes travel ban on President Yoon over martial law
Description: Yoon's martial law decree plunged South Korea into political turmoil and caused worry among its key diplomatic partners. (Image credit: Lee Jin-man)

Title: Russia targets Ukraine's energy grid as winter sets in. Here's how one plant copes
Description: Russian strikes continue to destroy Ukraine's power grid, prompting nationwide power cuts while temperatures drop. Workers at a damaged plant try to restore its operation before the winter freeze. (Image credit: Simona Supino for NPR)

Title: Mississippi communities scarred by ICE raids fear future under Trump
Description: Morton and nearby towns in central Mississippi saw the biggest workplace ICE raids in the country in 2019, when nearly 700 workers were arrested from chicken processing plants. Five years later, the impact is still felt here, even as activists and immigrants brace for more workplace raids under a second Trump term. (Image credit: Andrea Morales for NPR)

Title: What do Syrians make of all these seismic and rapid-fire events in their country?
Description: Syrians are celebrating the overthrow of longtime President Bashar al-Assad who fled Damascus, and has been given asylum in Russia.

Title: Workers at Volkswagen, Europe's biggest automaker, are on strike
Description: Volkswagen, Germany's largest employer, is facing backlash over its plans to cut wages, lay off workers, and close factories in Germany for the first time in its history.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Syrian rebels topple Bashar Assad's regime. The U.S. says it is prepared to work with Syrians creating a new government. President-elect Trump answers questions on NBC's 'Meet the Press.'

Title: Kennedy Center pays tribute to the Grateful Dead, Raitt, Sandoval and The Apollo
Description: A packed house honored the Grateful Dead, director Francis Ford Coppola, jazz trumpeter Arturo Sandoval and singer-songwriter Bonnie Raitt. The venerable Harlem theater The Apollo also was recognized. (Image credit: Manuel Balce Ceneta)

Title: Ruby slippers worn in 'The Wizard of Oz' are auctioned for a record $28 million
Description: Including the Dallas-based auction house's fee, the unknown buyer will ultimately pay $32.5 million for the pair of iconic ruby slippers that were stolen from a museum nearly two decades ago. (Image credit: Reed Saxon)

Title: Lawsuit accuses Jay-Z of raping a 13-year-old with Sean 'Diddy' Combs in 2000
Description: Shawn Carter, known professionally as Jay-Z, was added as a defendant on Sunday in a lawsuit first filed in October. The anonymous accuser said the assault happened at an MTV music awards after-party. (Image credit: Julio Cortez)

Title: Photos: See the fall of Damascus after Syrian rebels topple Assad's regime
Description: Assad's downfall came less than two weeks after an initial incursion west of the country's second largest city, Aleppo, triggered a cascading series of routs and retreats by the demoralized Syrian military. (Image credit: Omar Sanadiki)

Title: Syrians ransack Assad's private residence in Damascus after the regime's downfall
Description: The private residence of deposed Syrian leader Bashar al-Assad was ransacked after rebels took over the capital, forcing him to flee the country. (Image credit: Hussein Malla)

Title: Trump focuses on tariffs, not retribution, in first network TV interview
Description: President-elect Trump lays out plan for his first 100 days during interview with NBC News' 'Meet the Press.' (Image credit: Heather Khalifa)

Title: Cancer interrupted their school lives, but also set them on a mission
Description: Pediatric cancer survival rates are a crowning medical achievement. But the impact of missing school is a less-discussed side effect children then face. (Image credit: Beck family; José A. Alvarado Jr. for NPR)

Title: Syrian rebels take over the capital Damascus, forcing government to flee
Description: In a lightning campaign, Syrian rebels seize the capital and end half a century of brutal Assad family rule.

Title: After the fall of Assad, what comes next for Syria?
Description: NPR's Ayesha Rascoe speaks to Qutaiba Idlbi of the Atlantic Council about the fall of the Assad regime in Syria, considered one of the fiercest dictatorships in the world.

Title: They were supposed to get justice in court. Then, their alleged assaulter was found dead
Description: A former police officer died in an apparent suicide just before going to trial for sexual assault. His case was dismissed, and his alleged victims say they are infuriated.

Title: NYPD releases 2 new photos of man sought in killing of UnitedHealthcare CEO
Description: Late Saturday, police released two additional photos of the suspected shooter that appeared to be from a camera mounted inside a taxi. (Image credit: NYPD)

Title: Trapped in a Social Safety Net
Description: In 1972, the federal government launched a program to support the poorest disabled and elderly Americans. Supplemental Security Income, run by the Social Security Administration, provides monthly checks that are a lifeline for some of the most vulnerable people in this country.SSI was intended to serve as a powerful safety net and a tool for fighting poverty. But a recent NPR Investigation led by correspondent Joseph Shapiro has discovered a very different reality today.In today's episode of The Sunday Story, Shapiro explains how SSI's outdated rules have made the system difficult to run and almost impossible for its beneficiaries to navigate. Impoverished disabled and elderly people say they have been penalized for trying to improve their lives—for saving money, g...

Title: In Syria, the Assads leave a bitter legacy after a half-century of repressive rule
Description: President Bashar Assad and his father, Hafez Assad, combined to rule Syria for more than 50 years, always with an iron fist that crushed dissent and relied on the country's feared security forces. (Image credit: AP)

Title: Syrian government appears to have fallen in stunning end to long rule of Assad family
Description: The Syrian government appeared to have fallen early Sunday in a stunning end to the 50-year rule of the Assad family after a lightning rebel offensive. (Image credit: Omar Albam/AP)

Title: As Syrian civil war reignites, what are Vladimir Putin's ambitions there?
In France, Notre Dame Cathedral reopens in grand ceremony
Description: The Notre Dame Cathedral To Re-Open After Devastating Fire

Title: Photos: Notre Dame Cathedral reopens, with its first service since a devastating fire
Description: The bells of Notre Dame Cathedral rang on Saturday evening in Paris for the first time since a fire heavily damaged the Paris landmark in 2019. (Image credit: Ludovic Marin)

Title: Ukrainians face another harsh winter as Russia attacks coal country
Description: Many Ukrainians continue to leave their coal mining towns, with the front line of the war with Russia nearby. (Image credit: Michael Robinson Chávez for NPR)

Title: Syrian opposition activists say insurgents have reached the suburbs of Damascus
Description: Syrian insurgents have reached the suburbs of Damascus as part of a offensive that has seen them take over some of Syria's largest cities, opposition activists and a rebel commander said Saturday. (Image credit: Ghaith Alsayed)

Title: Syrian rebels make further inroads in major cities
Description: The Assad regime is Syria is looking increasingly fragile as rebels take control of more of the country's territory.

Title: How Russia's weakening economy could impact the war with Ukraine
Description: NPR's Elissa Nadworny talks with Alexandra Prokopenko, of the Carnegie Russia Eurasia Center, about weakness in the Russian economy and what that might mean for the country's war in Ukraine.

Title: Abortion access in Missouri is in limbo despite November's constitutional amendment
Description: Even though a new constitutional amendment is in effect in Missouri, a Planned Parenthood clinic in St. Louis can't provide abortions. They are waiting for a judge to end Missouri's ban.

Title: South Korean President Yoon's impeachment vote fails after ruling party boycotts it
Description: A South Korean legislative push to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol over his imposition of martial law fell through on Saturday. (Image credit: Ahn Young-joon)

Title: Activists worry that Trump will bulldoze trans rights. Here's how they're preparing
Description: Trump's campaign promised policies targeting the transgender community once he's in office. LGBTQ groups face fear, anxiety and uncertainty as they prep for an anticipated challenging four years. (Image credit: Drew Angerer)

Title: Internet sleuths are trying to solve the New York CEO killing
Description: The public is racing to find evidence that might lead to the gunman who killed health insurance CEO Brian Thompson. When does crowdsourcing detective work help police, and when can it cause harm? (Image credit: Ted Shaffrey)

Title: Trump travels to Paris for Notre Dame Cathedral's reopening and to meet with Macron
Description: Donald Trump is off on his first international trip as president-elect, ready to join world leaders and dignitaries in Paris for a Saturday celebration of the renovation of Notre Dame Cathedral. (Image credit: Christophe Petit Tesson)

Title: The latest on Austin Tice, an American journalist kidnapped in Syria in 2012
Description: Conflict between the Syrian government and rebel groups is raising uncertainty in the region. But in the chaos, some are optimistic about the possible release of American journalist Austin Tice.

Title: What does the Syrian rebel takeover mean for the Assad regime?
Description: Syrian rebels have taken two major cities and are closing in on a third. What does all this mean for the Assad regime?

Title: Will Assad Survive in Syria? And Will the Conflict Widen Into a Regional War?
Description: Rebels in Syria are making rapid advances against the government forces of President Bashar al-Assad. Assad has managed to stay in power throughout the civil war that has engulfed his country for more than a decade. But he again finds himself in a precarious position. We weigh the chances of his political survival. And in Lebanon, residents are watching as Syrian rebels get closer and closer to their border. There is concern that the fighting will spill over, threatening a fragile ceasefire between Israel and Hezbollah and perhaps becoming a regional war.

Title: Amid Israel-Hezbollah ceasefire, Lebanon is now worried about Syria too
Description: Under a shaky ceasefire with Israel, Lebanon has another worry: Syria. Border residents are doing armed patrols with Hezbollah. They fear Syrian rebels could invade them next. They've done it before.

Title: USDA orders testing across nation's milk supply amid rising bird flu cases
Description: The virus has spread to over 710 dairy herbs across 15 states, with California reporting the highest number of infections. At least 58 people have been infected with bird flu, including one child. (Image credit: Patrick T. Fallon)

Title: The holidays are peak time for volunteers, but how about the rest of the year?
Description: Thanksgiving Day kicks off a wave of volunteers stirred by the holiday spirit, but those in charge of local charities say they'd rather have that help at other times of the year. (Image credit: Andrew Stelzer for NPR)

Title: A body has been found in the search for a woman missing near a Pennsylvania sinkhole
Description: A Pennsylvania coroner's office said investigators believe they have located the body of 64-year-old Elizabeth Pollard, who was last seen four days earlier near a sinkhole above a shuttered coal mine. (Image credit: Matt Freed)

Title: She's 74 — and expecting: Wisdom the albatross astounds once again
Description: It started in the Eisenhower era: Every year, Wisdom, a Layan albatross, has returned to her nesting grounds on the Midway Atoll in the Pacific Ocean. (Image credit: Dan Rapp)

Title: After trying to impose martial law, South Korea's president faces an impeachment vote
Description: After President Yoon Suk Yeol's failed attempt to impose martial law, South Korea's parliament will vote Saturday on his impeachment. Yoon's own party chief has called for his powers to be suspended. (Image credit: Jung-Yeon-Je)

Title: Concerns over Trump's crypto promises. And, gift ideas for 5 personality types
Description: President-elect Donald Trump has promised to make the U.S. the planet's 'crypto capital.' Here's why critics are concerned. And, gift ideas this holiday season for five personality types. (Image credit: Omar Albam)

Title: The regime of Syrian President Bashar Assad is looking increasingly fragile
Description: Rebel insurgents swept into Hama as the Syrian army withdrew. The move puts the rebel fighters even closer to the Syrian capitol Damascus, and deals another blow to President Bashar Assad.

Title: A cancer survivor nearly died trying to prove he had recovered
Description: In this week's StoryCorps, two friends recall a harrowing ski trip in the Colorado mountains.

Title: New York City has a housing shortage. Officials are trying to change that
Description: Officials in New York City are close to approving zoning changes that could increase the amount of housing available. How will this impact housing availability and access?

Title: Police are still looking for the suspect in the shooting of the UnitedHealthcare CEO
Description: The manhunt for the person who fatally shot the head of one of the country's largest health insurers in New York City entered its third day Friday as police parsed newly discovered clues. (Image credit: Yuki Iwamura)

Title: Who or what else did President Biden pardon? Find out in the quiz!
Description: Also in your grab bag of weekly trivia: martial law, bitcoin, the first lady's holiday décor, a Kennedy who's not RFK Jr., brain rot and the popemobile.

Title: Syrian opposition forces enter a key city -- in a new blow to Assad regime
Description: In Syria, government forces retreat as rebels capture key cities. The rebels' stunning advance raises questions about the survival of the Bashar al-Assad regime.

Title: Minneapolis City Council explores options for George Floyd Square
Description: George Floyd's killing by police in 2020 sparked worldwide protests. Minneapolis wants to make changes to George Floyd Square -- the multi-block memorial that occupies the area where Floyd died.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Syrian opposition forces enter a key city, in a new blow to Assad regime. President-elect Trump announces White House AI and Crypto Czar. New York City takes a step toward addressing housing crisis.

Title: 3 climbers from the U.S. and Canada are believed to have died in New Zealand
Description: Three mountain climbers — two from the U.S. and one from Canada — missing for five days on Aoraki, New Zealand's tallest peak, are believed to have died in a fall, the authorities said Friday. (Image credit: Mark Baker)

Title: Trump names former Sen. David Perdue of Georgia to be ambassador to China
Description: With his nomination, Trump is leaning on a former business executive-turned politician to serve as the administration's envoy to America's most potent economic and military adversary.

Title: Trump nominates Rodney Scott to lead Customs and Border Protection
Description: Rodney Scott at CBP and Caleb Vitello at ICE would work alongside Stephen Miller, who was named deputy chief of staff for policy and Tom Homan, also tapped to be a 'border czar.' (Image credit: Matt York/AP)

Title: At Miami's Art Basel fair, elephants and a buried ship are bringing out the locals
Description: Rising from the sand on Miami Beach are what appear to be the sails of a buried Spanish galleon. It's a piece created by Tlingit/Unangax artist Nicholas Galanin. (Image credit: Greg Allen)

Title: Memphis police regularly violate civil rights, DOJ finds
Description: The Justice Department finds Memphis police regularly violate the civil rights of citizens, engaging in unconstitutional tactics like excessive use of force and discriminating against Black residents.

Title: Former detective weighs in on the hunt for the UnitedHealthcare CEO's killer
Description: NPR's Ailsa Chang talks with David Sarni, a retired NYPD detective and adjunct professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, about the hunt for the gunman who killed the UnitedHealthcare CEO.

Title: Syrians in Aleppo show cautious optimism amid rebel takeover
Description: Syrians in Aleppo are cautiously optimistic as rebel groups take over Assad-regime held areas of their country.

Title: Protecting Unique Wilderness at the Bottom of the World
Description: Chile is poised to create it's 47th national part in the coming year, protecting wilderness at the southern tip of South America. That's thanks in large part to the work of a U.S. conservationist and her organization. We go to the bottom of the world to see the stunning landscape that will make up the park.

Title: Some rural Nevadans want Trump to stop the state's solar energy boom
Description: Backlash against massive solar energy farms drove strong rural turnout in Nevada may have helped flip the presidential vote there to Republican for the first time since 2004. But it's not a given Trump will derail President Biden's plans for more Nevada solar. (Image credit: Ethan Miller/Getty Images)

Title: France's toppled government adds to the European Union's bigger political problems
Description: The political instability in France — and simultaneously in Germany, where the governing coalition collapsed a month ago — could have wide-ranging consequences. (Image credit: Telmo Pinto)

Title: Search continues for the person who shot and killed UnitedHealthcare CEO
Description: The search continues for the person who shot and killed the CEO of UnitedHealthcare outside a Manhattan hotel yesterday. Police have said it was a target, pre-planned attack.

Title: Insurgents gain ground in Syria. What happens now?
Description: Syrian anti-government insurgents claim they have entered the city of Hama — a major Syrian government stronghold.This continues their momentum over the last week, when they also seized Syria's second largest city, Aleppo. Since the war started in 2011, half a million people have been killed and many millions of others displaced.The Syrian Civil War has been locked in a stalemate for years. Now, rebel forces are gaining ground against the oppressive regime of Bashar al-Assad. Will the group ultimately end his control over the country?For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.Email us at considerthis@npr...

Title: How worried should we be about Disease X?
Description: An unidentified illness has claimed 80 lives in DRC. Investigators are on the scenes to determine what it is — and how much of a threat it poses to locally and globally (Image credit: PeterHermesFurian/Getty Images/iStockphoto)

Title: Pope Francis goes electric in new eco-friendly popemobile
Description: Pope Francis, who heads the Catholic Church, has doubled down on his commitment to the environment with a new electric popemobile presented by Mercedes-Benz. (Image credit: Filippo Monteforte/AFP)

Title: A powerful 7.0 earthquake strikes off northern California coast; tsunami warning issued
Description: A powerful earthquake has struck off the northern California coast and a tsunami warning has been issued. Several aftershocks continue to rattle the area off Eureka. (Image credit: Jenny Kane)

Title: Court rejects Boeing plea deal stemming from 737 Max crashes
Description: A federal judge in Texas has rejected a plea deal between Boeing and the U.S. Justice Department, saying the court should play a bigger role in selecting an independent monitor to oversee the company. (Image credit: David Ryder)

Title: Memphis police use excessive force and discriminate against Black people, the DOJ finds
Description: A Justice Department investigation launched after the beating death of Tyre Nichols in 2023 found that 'Memphis police officers regularly violate the rights of the people they are sworn to serve.' (Image credit: Gerald Herbert)

Title: Cryptic words were found on bullet casings at scene of CEO Brian Thompson's killing
Description: Shell casings with the cryptic words 'deny,' 'defend' and 'depose' were found at the scene of the fatal shooting of the UnitedHealthcare CEO outside of a Manhattan hotel, police officials say. (Image credit: New York Police Department)

Title: Amnesty International accuses Israel of genocide in Gaza, which Israel strongly denies
Description: Amnesty International says Israel has sought to deliberately destroy Palestinians in its war with Hamas, by mounting deadly attacks, demolishing vital infrastructure and preventing aid deliveries. (Image credit: Fatima Shbair)

Title: Anthem plans to put time limits on anesthesia coverage, alarming doctors
Description: Anthem Blue Cross Blue Shield says it will put time limits on anesthesia care starting next year. Doctors and elected officials, including in New York and Connecticut, are asking it to change course. (Image credit: Michael Conroy)

Title: Syrian opposition forces enter the strategic city of Hama
Description: Syrian rebels have entered another major city, in a further blow to President Bashar Assad after they took over Aleppo days earlier. (Image credit: Omar Albam)

Title: Syrian opposition forces enter strategic city of Hama
Description: Syrian rebels have entered a second city in yet another blow to the President Bashar al-Assad after they took over Syria's second city only days before. (Image credit: Omar Albam)

Title: Post Hurricane Helene: People in western North Carolina feel the cold weather
Description: People displaced by Hurricane Helene and living in temporary shelters, are trying to stay warm this week as freezing temperatures blanket the region.

Title: The CEO of a health insurance giant is gunned down on a busy Manhattan street
Description: New York police say Brian Thompson, CEO of UnitedHealthcare, the country's largest health insurer, was the target of a preplanned attack. Authorities are searching for the person who did it.

Title: An unknown infant was rushed to a Gaza hospital. A nurse gave her a name, and a home
Description: The newborn, found by rescuers after an Israeli attack, was rushed to a hospital. Nurse Amal Abu Khatleh gave her the name Malak, meaning angel. She is raising the baby until relatives can be found. (Image credit: Amal Abu Khatleh)

Title: Long before this week, South Korea had a painful history with martial law
Description: In 1980, violent clashes between government forces and pro-democracy demonstrators in the southwestern city of Gwangju created lasting scars that continue to shape South Korea to this day. (Image credit: File)

Title: How a staffing shortage can make special education jobs more dangerous
Description: Special educators are more likely to experience violence or aggression from students. That can make hiring a challenge, at a time when schools nationwide are struggling to fill these positions. (Image credit: Samuel Rocha IV)

Title: Comparing the current protests in Georgia with Ukraine's 2014 revolution
Description: There are parallels between the demonstrations in the Republic of Georgia and Ukraine's 2014 revolution. One expert says while there are many similarities, there is one big difference to consider.

Title: French Prime Minister Michel Barnier and his cabinet lose no-confidence vote
Description: The French government has fallen in a no-confidence vote, and the prime minister is resigning. President Emmanuel Macron has cut short a trip to Saudi Arabia to return and address the nation.

Title: Lessons learned from when the Obama administration deported millions of people
Description: Could deporting immigrants open up their jobs for Americans? President Obama's administration deported more than 3 million people, and an economist studied those effects.

Title: Why access to abortion in Missouri is in limbo
Description: Missouri voters moved to end the state's strict abortion ban in the November election but it's unclear whether the treatment will be available Thursday, the deadline for the amendment to take effect.

Title: Why a Florida Democrat joined the DOGE caucus that's looking to cut federal spending
Description: Democratic Rep. Jared Moskowitz of Florida tells Morning Edition that members of his party need to be in the room when conversations about cutting government spending and efficiency are happening. (Image credit: Jose Luis Magana)

Title: Amnesty International is officially calling Israel's war in Gaza a genocide
Description: The human rights group says Israel acted with intent to commit genocide against Palestinians, alongside its war against Hamas.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Donald Trump's pick for defense secretary fights to save nomination. Manhunt is underway in NYC for the person who killed UnitedHealthcare's CEO. How would mass deportations affect U.S. job market?

Title: The Black Gate: Vanished in the Night
Description: In the Xinjiang region of western China, the government has rounded up and detained hundreds of thousands of Uyghurs and other Muslim ethnic groups, including the wife and young children of a Uyghur businessman named Abdullatif Kucar. NPR correspondent Emilly Feng follows Kucar as he desperately searches for his missing family. To listen to this series sponsor-free and support NPR, sign up for Embedded+ in Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Title: Mexican troops seize a record fentanyl haul in northern Sinaloa state
Description: Mexican soldiers and marines have seized over a ton of fentanyl pills in two raids in the north, with officials calling it the biggest catch of the synthetic opioid in the country's history. (Image credit: Martin Urista)

Title: Legendary Medellin cartel drug lord released from U.S. prison after serving 25 years
Description: One of Colombia's legendary drug lords has been released from prison and is expected to be deported. Ochoa was first indicted in the U.S. for his alleged role in the 1986 killing of a DEA informant. (Image credit: AP)

Title: A major power plant fails in Cuba, plunging the island into darkness — again
Description: The blackout, on Wednesday, affected the entire nation, leaving millions without electricity and forcing authorities to suspend classes and work activities indefinitely. (Image credit: Ramon Espinosa)

Title: Trump is already making foreign policy plans
Description: Every time a presidential transition takes place, a familiar phrase crops up: 'the U.S. has one president at a time.' But Trump is already declaring foreign policy plans that differ from Biden's.

Title: The U.S. and China Vie for Influence in Africa
Description: Joe Biden's first and last trip to Africa as president wrapped up in a port city in Angola. It's the end of an 800 mile train line connecting the port to massive mineral deposits in Central Africa. The U.S. and other Western countries are raising billions to upgrade the rail line, a move that is seen as an effort to counter China's investments in mining in the region. We go to one of the mining cities along that train route to see how the geopolitics are playing out. Support NPR and get sponsor-free episodes of State of the World. Sign up for NPR+ at plus.npr.org

Title: The killing of the UnitedHealthcare CEO was a targeted attack, authorities say
Description: The CEO of United Healthcare was shot and killed in what New York City officials are calling a brazen and targeted attack. The company has the largest share of the nation's health insurance market.

Title: French lawmakers oust the prime minister after just 91 days, toppling the government
Description: France's government has been toppled by a no-confidence vote in parliament, for the first time sine 1962. Prime Minister Michel Barnier served the shortest time in the post in France's modern history. (Image credit: Michel Euler)
